question.name: Question 1
question.text: Who is NOT an officer of a business?
question.correctans: Anyone who influences the business's reputation
question.choices: Anyone who has the capacity to significantly alter the corporation's financial standing|Anyone who is appointed as an officer of an unincorporated association|Anyone who influences the business's reputation|Anyone who makes decisions that affect a substantial part of the business

question.name: Question 2
question.text: Complete the sentence. You are likely to be considered an officer if you are\u2026
question.correctans: \u2026 a company director, company secretary or executive officer
question.choices: \u2026 a company secretary, WHS representative or union representative|\u2026 a worker of any description|\u2026 executive officer, secretarial staff or WHS representative|\u2026 a company director, company secretary or executive officer

question.name: Question 3
question.text: In what Act is an officer of a PCBU defined?
question.choices: Fair Work Act|Work Health and Safety Act|Corporations Act |All of the above

question.name: Question 4
question.text: Complete the sentence. At minimum, officers of a PCBU must take reasonable steps to\u2026
question.correctans: \u2026 acquire and keep up-to-date knowledge of work health and safety matters
question.choices: \u2026 acquire and keep up-to-date knowledge of work health and safety matters|\u2026 delegate their due diligence obligations|\u2026 exercise maximum skill|\u2026 take all possible measures

question.name: Question 5
question.text: What steps an officer must take to fulfil his or her due diligence obligation depends on what factors?
question.choices: Position, responsibilities and authority of the officer and what is reasonable in the circumstances|What duties the PCBU owes|Nature of risks to health and safety posed by the particular business or undertaking|All of the above

question.name: Question 6
question.text: How can an officer exercise due diligence?
question.correctans: By gaining an understanding of the nature of the PCBU\u2019s business operations and the associated risks
question.choices: By keeping up-to-date with the news|By checking whether competitors have appropriate processes about hazards and incidents|By ensuring that workers implement processes to ensure the PCBU complies with its obligations under the Act|By gaining an understanding of the nature of the PCBU\u2019s business operations and the associated risks

question.name: Question 7
question.text: In order for an officer to defend a claim by showing that they exercised due diligence to prevent a breach, the officer will need to show what?
question.correctans: That the organisation has an effective work health and safety system
question.choices: That the business is financially viable|That the organisation has an effective work health and safety system|That the officer is a very careful person|That the officer regrets the breach

question.name: Question 8
question.text: What is NOT part of an effective WHS safety system?
question.choices: Hazard analysis and risk management systems|Documented internal reporting systems|Regular efficiency audits|Education and awareness programs for workers

question.name: Question 9
question.text: In addition to demonstrating due diligence, what else does an officer need to show?
question.choices: That he or she has a good understanding of the hazards and risks associated with the operations |That he or she has a good understanding of the PCBU's approach to managing the hazards and risks|That he or she has directed adequate resources to WHS initiatives|All of the above

question.name: Question 10
question.text: Complete the sentence. Breach of due diligence under the WHS law is \u2026
question.choices: \u2026 a criminal offence|\u2026 punishable only by a small fine|\u2026 a public nuisance|\u2026 not an offence

question.name: Question 11
question.text: If a company breaches its WHS duties, an officer may be held personally liable unless the officer can show that he or she\u2026
question.correctans: \u2026 exercised all due diligence to prevent the breach
question.choices: \u2026 was not at work when the breach occurred|\u2026 did not cause the breach|\u2026 was not injured by the breach|\u2026 exercised all due diligence to prevent the breach

question.name: Question 12
question.text: An officer owes a duty to exercise due diligence to ensure the PCBU complies with all its duties and obligations under the WHS Act. True or false?

question.name: Question 13
question.text: Complete the sentence. If a PCBU breaches their H&S duty and is reckless to the risk of death, then\u2026
question.correctans: \u2026 they have committed a Category 1 offence; the most serious type of offence under WHS law
question.choices: \u2026 they have committed a Category 1 offence; the most serious type of offence under WHS law|\u2026 they have committed a Category 3 offence; a relatively minor offence under WHS law|\u2026 the PCBU's officers can face only severe monetary penalties|\u2026 they will not be penalised unless an individual actually dies as a result of the breach

question.name: Question 14
question.text: Complete the sentence. PCBUs commit a Category 2 offence if\u2026
question.correctans: \u2026 they fail to comply with their health and safety duty, and they expose an individual to risk of death, serious injury or serious illness
question.choices: \u2026 they fail to comply with a health and safety duty which they owe|\u2026 an individual is exposed to a risk of death, serious injury or serious illness, then they can be found guilty of a Category 2 offence if they were reckless in their conduct|\u2026 officers fail to exercise due diligence|\u2026 they fail to comply with their health and safety duty, and they expose an individual to risk of death, serious injury or serious illness

question.name: Question 15
question.correctans: \u2026 involve a failure to comply with a health and safety duty
question.choices: \u2026 are more serious than other categories of offences|\u2026 can only be committed by small, privately-owned organisations|\u2026 involve a failure to comply with a health and safety duty that exposes an individual to the risk of serious injury, illness or death|\u2026 involve a failure to comply with a health and safety duty
